overview: 2 Kings continues the history of the divided kingdom through its tragic end. The northern kingdom falls to Assyria, and Judah eventually falls to Babylon, fulfilling prophetic warnings about covenant unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Yet the LORD warned Israel and Judah by every prophet and every seer, saying, 'Turn from your evil ways and keep my commandments and my statutes.'
And as they still went on and talked, behold, chariots of fire and horses of fire separated the two of them. And Elijah went up by a whirlwind into heaven.
Then he returned to the man of God, he and all his company, and he came and stood before him. And he said, 'Behold, I know that there is no God in all the earth but in Israel.'

passages.title: Elijah's Departure
passages.summary: Elijah is taken to heaven in a whirlwind with chariots of fire. Elisha receives his mantle and a double portion of his spirit.

passages.title: Naaman's Healing
passages.summary: A Syrian general with leprosy is healed by washing in the Jordan River, learning that Israel's God is the only true God.

passages.title: The Fall of Jerusalem
passages.summary: Babylon destroys Jerusalem and the temple, taking Judah into exile. The Davidic line continues, but the kingdom is lost.

facts.text: The northern kingdom of Israel fell to Assyria in 722 BC. Its people were scattered and never returned as a distinct nation.
Judah fell to Babylon in 586 BC, exactly as prophets like Jeremiah had warned for decades.
Elisha performed twice as many recorded miracles as Elijah, receiving the 'double portion' he requested.
Good kings like Hezekiah and Josiah brought spiritual reforms, but couldn't ultimately prevent judgment for the nation's accumulated sin.

figures.name: Elisha
figures.description: Elijah's successor who received a double portion of his spirit. He performed many miracles including healing Naaman and raising the dead.

figures.name: Hezekiah
figures.description: A good king of Judah who trusted God during Assyria's siege. God miraculously delivered Jerusalem and added 15 years to his life.

figures.name: Josiah
figures.description: Judah's last good king who rediscovered the Book of the Law and led national repentance, though it couldn't avert coming judgment.

figures.name: Naaman
figures.description: A Syrian military commander whose leprosy was healed when he obeyed Elisha's simple instruction to wash in the Jordan River.

videos.title: 2 Kings Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project traces the tragic decline and fall of both Israelite kingdoms.
